course.subject: LANG
course.name: Chinese for Non-Chinese Language Background Students I
course.description: Introduction to Chinese language and culture; basic understanding of Putonghua phonology and Chinese syntax; basic communicative competence in Chinese; recognition of high‐frequency Chinese characters. The course is restricted to students with non‐Chinese language backgrounds. Instructors’ approval is required for students with Chinese backgrounds who are from international schools of Hong Kong, China Mainland and other Asian countries, also for overseas students with either Mandarin or Cantonese language backgrounds.
course.exclusions: HKDSE/HKALE/HKCEE/JEE Chinese, LANG 1113, LANG 1114 (prior to 2017-18), LANG 1115 (prior to 2017-18), LANG 1116 (prior to 2017-18), LANG 1117, LANG 1118

reviews.author: Ishi
reviews.title: LANG1120
reviews.comment_content:
This course teaches basic mandarin, I think that the content will really help international students living in Hong Kong. The course has 3 units. The first unit looks at greetings, introduction, and daily conversations. The second unit is all about numbers (counting, date, prices). The last unit is harder and looks at making telephone calls, your likes and dislikes, food, and hobbies.

In my opinion, it is not too difficult altogether, and the previous units give you a good base for the last unit.
reviews.comment_teaching:
My teacher was amazing. She not only taught us the syllabus but also extra words and phrases. She never stopped us from asking questions even though it used to slow down the class sometimes. Sometimes she has short quizzes about topics covered in the last class, but they are not graded.

Resources provided are also very good. Make sure you use CLE website.
reviews.comment_grading:
3 assignments:
Assessment 1 (20%) - Listening, covering unit 1 (chapters 1-3)

Assessment 2 (20%) - Listening & oral test, covering unit 2 (chapters 4-7)

Assessment 3 (50%) - Oral and listening test covering unit 3 (chapters 8-10) + grammar test and character recognition covering units 1, 2, & 3.

Essay (10%) - You also have to write an essay about Chinese culture, has to be 1000 words or less.

Attendance is not part of the grade. However, five absences may result in an F.

I think the grading is ok. Liang Xin told us that she tried to give us as many marks as she could. However, I noticed that in the oral tests the grading was quite harsh. Some international students have difficulty with pronunciation.

Assessment 1: Listening - 10/10, Oral - 9.2/10
Assessment 2: Listening - 9.5/10, Oral - 18/21
Assessment 3: (Scores were not given)
Grade: A+
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is medium. It really depends on what kind of grade you want. My teacher gave homework from time to time but it took only 15 minutes or so. There aren't any consequences if you don't do the homework but in my experience, doing the homework really helps in the assessments.

I recommend that you keep revising the content over the semester, then the assessments become quite easy. After mid-semester, you should also start memorizing characters. Flashcards really helped me with character recognition.

reviews.author: abpuma
reviews.comment_content:
Most of the course content is quite useful. There are ten chapter which are based on ten everyday topics. But, the course is quite in-depth for a beginner course and so, it can get quite challenging. There is an attendance requirement, missing more than 5 classes is an automatic fail.

There are three assessments throughout the course. There is also an essay on Chinese culture.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Nuo is a excellent teacher and is know as the best one in the three teacher who teach this course. She likes to go over the curriculum requirements and frequently gives a lot of additional information.

Try to read the textbook before you go to class.
reviews.comment_grading:
There is absolute grading i.e. no grading curve. The grading follows 5% increments such that:
95-100 = A+
90-95 = A
85-90 = A–
and so on
reviews.comment_workload: The course has a significant workload. Two of the 3 assessments have an oral presentation which you need to memorize in advance. The character recognition is also quite difficult to prepare. You need to be attentive and practising right from the first class to have a balanced workload towards the end.

reviews.author: wbs77
reviews.title: pretty good class
reviews.comment_content:
Unit One
1) Greetings
2) Making new friends  
3) introduction

Unit Two
1) How much is it?
2) When do you have class?
3) When do you go to Shanghai?
4) Do you have time to join my birthday party?

Unit Three
1) What do you like to eat?
2) I will have a bowl of noodles.
3) Give me a call.

Fairly easy topics. The pace of the class is really fast though. You also need to learn around 100 characters which are not taught in class. The content follows the book directly.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teacher is really nice. Cares for students and answers a lot of questions. The only problem might be that sometimes the content taught in class isn’t directly translated in the written exam because the class is mainly focused on speaking.
reviews.comment_grading:
There are 4 total assessments;
Assessment 1: Pronunciation (10%) and listening (10%)
Assessment 2: Oral (15%) and listening (10%)
Assessment 3: Chinese culture essay (10%)
Assessment 4: Oral (15%) , listening (10%) , grammar (10%) and character recognition (10%)

Pretty fair grading. Nearly absolute grading.
reviews.comment_workload: Not much workload. Pretty normal amount of homework. We usually would get one piece of homework per class but it could usually be done in 30 minutes.

reviews.author: skyfundjr
reviews.comment_content: For the content, it basically covers the basic of Chinese. You will start from four tones and you will not asked to memorize Chinese characters until the final assessment. However, it does not mean that  you should not study the characters during the semesters. It is highly recommended for you to study characters from the beginning.
reviews.comment_teaching: It is uncontroversial that the professor has great teaching skill. She is perfectly adequate to the students with first time studying Chinese.
reviews.comment_grading: Although the 3rd assessment is very difficult, the grading system is generally reasonable. If you put enough time, you can achieve the grade you want.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is very light compare to other classes. However, be aware to put a lot of effort.

reviews.author: kyla
reviews.title: You Better Study
reviews.comment_content: The course has 3 parts. They are progressively taught faster and faster. The first unit looks at greetings, introduction, and daily conversations. The second unit is about dates, prices and counting. The last unit consists of making telephone calls, likes and dislikes, and what you do in your freetime.
reviews.comment_teaching: Nuo, Min is really nice and is definitely a good teacher. She does teach quite fast so you cannot slack off - you need to be 100% present during class. She is super nice though and will answer any questions you have.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is quite strict but not impossible. It is very hard to get a perfect mark, but if you try hard enough and study your booty off then you can make satisfactory marks. It is very basic Chinese for a non-Chinese speaker it is definitely difficult.
reviews.comment_workload: Just studying you have to keep up with and before the quizzes it is necessary. There are two spoken presentations that you must practice but the tip is to have a native Chinese speaker to record a voice memo of your speech so you know how it is supposed to sound, and practice based off of that.

reviews.author: Zakk
reviews.title: LANG 1120 Course Review
reviews.comment_content:
From the very basics of Mandarin - the tones - to the basics of everyday conversation.

Topics are:

Unit One
Lesson 1 Greetings
Lesson 2 Making new friends
Lesson 3 Introduction

Unit Two
Lesson 4 How much is it?
Lesson 5 When do you have class?
Lesson 6 When do you go to Shanghai?
Lesson 7 Do you have time to join my birthday party?

Unit Three
Lesson 8 What do you like to eat?
Lesson 9 I will have a bowl of noodles.
Lesson 10 Give me a call.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The teaching is very nice, as the class size is only 20 people.

The professor is very nice and engaging - she may seem serious in  the first lecture, but afterwards, she is very good at teaching and really cares about the students.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is absolute.

Three Assessments:

Assessment 1: Listening and Tone Pronunciation
Assessment 2: Oral Speech + Listening
Assessment 3: Oral Speech + Listening + Character Recognition + Grammar

One Essay on an Aspect of Chinese Culture
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is very dependent on your memorization skills, as it is a basics language course. Most of the work is memorization, except for the essay, which won't take you too long either.

Hardest part is the oral speeches - pay great mind to the variety of sentences AND vocab, along with the tones of the words.

Overall it is not bad at all.

The pace of learning is very fast for a basics course, but it is useful.

reviews.author: _dg
reviews.comment_content:
This course is a requirement for all international students and includes basic Mandarin, which can actually prove to be quite helpful. But the content can be very hard to deal with, if not reviewed on a regular basis.

The course has 3 units. The first unit looks at greetings, introduction, and daily conversations. The second unit is all about numbers (counting, date, prices). The last unit is harder and looks at making telephone calls, your likes and dislikes, food, and hobbies.

In my opinion, the key is to not stall with reviewing the content after every class. It can be very overwhelming to do all the content right before the exam. So to the typical UST student, DO NOT PROCRASTINATE.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Emma is actually a great teacher and she has a lot of patience. I took the online version of the class with her in Spring 2020 and she made sure to give personal attention to every kid in the class.

Also, she is I think the only prof out of all teaching the course, who gives insights on the examination pattern and what the scoring will be like. That is pretty helpful, and she is also very generous with offering time outside class to help with doubts.
reviews.comment_grading:
1. Assessment 1:
Pronunciation (10%)
Listening (5%)

2. Assessment 2:
Oral 1 (15%)
Listening (5%)

3. Assessment 3:
Oral 2 (15%)
Listening (10%)
Grammar (10%)
Character recognition (10%)

4. Essay of around 1000 English words about Chinese culture (10%)

5. Participation (10%)

The grading is absolute, and you need to score an aggregate of 90% or above to get A or more. I scored a total percentage of around 88% in total and secured an A-, pretty satisfied considering how hard it was for me to get by.
reviews.comment_workload:
If you want to score well, you might have to put in effort because you wont be able to just wing it. Taking the online version was definitely a bit easier because we got to record our oral presentations and hence could rerecord if an error was made; opposed to the offline exam where you just get one shot.

My advise would be to practice vocabulary after every class for a bit, so you can retain what was taught. I didn't do that, and hence had to do everything at the last moment.

reviews.comment_teaching: Emma Rao is a pretty nice teacher. She tries her best to explain everything. The slides she makes have a lot of extra information. She will have practice conversations with you during class and often will help you with pronunciation. Before the speaking task, I would recommend that you show her your script, she will help out with the pronunciation and the grammar.
reviews.comment_grading:
3 assessments:
Assessment 1 (20%) - Listening, covering unit 1 (chapters 1-3)

Assessment 2 (20%) - Listening & oral test, covering unit 2 (chapters 4-7)

Assessment 3 (50%) - Oral and listening test covering unit 3 (chapters 8-10) + grammar test and character recognition covering units 1, 2, & 3.

Essay (10%) - You also have to write an essay about Chinese culture, which has to be 1000 words or less.

Emma is a very strict grader. She expects a really high-quality speech during the speaking task, with perfect pronunciation. Practice for your speech beforehand to get a good grade.
reviews.comment_workload: If you want to get an A range you have to work really hard. Practice vocabulary for at least 2 hours every week. There are assessments every other week. A lot of new words are introduced in the last unit, so it gets very intense. I would recommend reading the textbook over break if you have the time.

reviews.author: ogt
reviews.title: Great course!
reviews.comment_content: Covers all the basic content you would expect in an introductory language course. It is very interesting and will teach you how to introduce yourself, your friends & family within the first month. The second and third months build on what you have already learned, such as how to order food, talking about your schedule, your activities, expressing what you like/dislike.
reviews.comment_teaching:
It is quite fast-paced but the teacher is very knowledgeable and helpful. She always makes an effort to make sure we understand everything and pronounce words properly.
By the end of the semester, she knew most people's names too.
Overall, I liked the teaching very much!
reviews.comment_grading:
I think the grading is very fair. The grade heavily depends on how much work you've put in.
For the oral tasks, I would highly recommend putting in as much information as possible. Make it longer than the minimum 3 minutes (both of mine were +7min long) because the teacher grades the content section based on the different vocabulary you use. Go through the book thoroughly adding every piece of vocab you can and re-use the grammar examples to get a high score on the grammar section. Additionally, I would recommend starting preparing your oral as soon as possible and putting in a good effort to learn it properly, as a fluent oral will make you win points on the pronunciation/fluency section.
The grammar task was quite difficult, you must go through every point covered in the book before hand.
Overall, you don't need to worry too much as long as you've worked throughout the semester.
Final grade: A
reviews.comment_workload:
To learn all the vocab, you must spend 10mn a day doing flashcards, practicing tone recognition etc. It's not a massive workload but you'll be doing Chinese everyday. I recommend using your time in the elevators to do your flashcards.
After the first 2 months, it gets easier learning the vocab because you have a better understanding of the language, tones etc.

reviews.author: mylittlepony
reviews.title: Reaaaallllllyyyyyyy long lessons - if you work hard you'll get a good grade
reviews.comment_content:
As the course is only one month long, everything is sort of crammed in. Normally lessons will be about 3 hours long and you will have two 10 minute breaks.

The topics covered are:
1) Self Introduction
2) How to speak about your friends/family
3) Numbers
4) Food
5) Likes and dislikes/hobbies
reviews.comment_teaching:
The teacher is amazing, super friendly and always willing to give you advice as to how you can perform better in exams. She will also do her best to give you the best grade possible.

Definitely one of the best teachers I've had in UST.
reviews.comment_grading:
Absolute Grading. Every 5% you go down a grade -
95-100% = A+
90-95% = A
85 -90% = A-
And so on.........

Throughout the one month course, you will have three assessments (basically 1 exam per week and a half)  in which a variety of skills will be tested. On top of that, you must also write a 1000 word essay in English, about something to do with Chinese heritage/Culture.

1) Assesment 1 = 20%
     * Pronounciation - 10%
     * Listening - 10%
2) Assesment 2  = 20%
     * Oral - 10%
     * Listening -  10%
3) Assesment 3 = 50%
     * Oral - 10%
     * Listening - 10%
     * Grammar - 20%
     * Character Recognition - 10%
4) 1000 word English Essay = 10%

Overall, I got 69.689% and got a B-

* Work hard during the course and you'll do well! I didn't study much at all and was quite disappointed with my grade, considering I gave up my summer holiday to do summer school.
reviews.comment_workload: Not very heavy, I think if you review the work after each lesson and spend about 45 minutes a day on the work you can definitely get an A grade range. I spent about 5 hours in total, outside class and got a B-.

reviews.comment_workload: I spent more time studying Chinese than I did studying all my other courses together, I wouldn't recommend taking this course with zero prior knowledge, learn some over a break before enrolling.

reviews.author: mowa
reviews.comment_content: The course is divided into 3 units. The first one is about tones, pronunciation, greetings, and introduction. The second unit is about numbers, date, month, and year. And the last unit is about foods, drinks, hobbies, likes, and dislikes.
reviews.comment_teaching: She is a really great teacher. She teaches patiently and passionately. She always tries to make every student participate in the class to make sure that we understand the lesson.
reviews.comment_grading:
There are 3 assessments in total

Assessment 1
Listening 10%
Pronunciation 10%

Assessment 2
Listening 10%
Oral 10%

Assessment 3
Listening 10%
Oral 10%
Grammar 20%
Character recognition 10%

Essay of Chinese culture in English (1000 words) 10%

It's not hard to get an A range grade if you really pay attention to the class and make sure to review before the assessment. The oral scoring is based on your content, grammar, and pronunciation. You can get a pretty high score in the content area by including as many vocabularies that have been taught in the lesson as possible in your script.
reviews.comment_workload: The only workload outside the class is the essay. The other thing that might consume your time is the preparation for each assessment as you might need to make an oral script if you are a beginner in Mandarin (you cannot take it with you for the assessment though) and to review the materials.

reviews.comment_grading: Not very harsh grading, especially for speaking, but never gives full mark on speaking! I think I got what I deserved for the class.
reviews.comment_workload: Depends on whether if you work on the chapters for the next class, do the exercises that she suggests.

reviews.author: therock
reviews.title: Insane Pace
reviews.comment_content:
10 chapters, topics include:
- greetings/basic communication
- introductions (+friends, family)
- numbers (+time, money)
- phone calls
- likes/dislikes
- food/drinks
- activities

WAY too much is covered in a short amount of time. For example, instead of learning some basic words for food, we learn the most obscure food names that I definitely don't need in the first 3 months of learning chinese (steamed fish wtf? didnt even know that was a thing). I probably learned more vocab in the 3 months of learning Chinese than in a year of French. It's ridiculous, no one will remember half the stuff in a month.
reviews.comment_teaching: Started out strong, but got worse as the weeks went by. By the end I barely paid attention in class because the teaching seemed kinda useless, just throwing vocab at us and then acting surprised when we couldn't remember everything since week 1. Could be my own fault though, so shouldn't blame the teacher.
reviews.comment_grading:
20% Test 1: Listening, Pronunciation (super strict on tones)
20% Test 2: Listening, Oral (don't get too excited when you get 100% on super easy listening test, the oral will fck you up)
10% Essay (honestly no idea how they even come up with scores for this)
50% Test 3: Oral (again, beware), Listening, Grammar, Character Recognition (don't expect to go much over this in class, pretty much self-study all the characters)
I'm so grateful grading is absolute, but then comes the essay and oral presentations where, from the getgo, Emma tells us pretty much no one will score 7/7. Obviously, I get that, but then I had no idea how harsh she'd actually be. Especially for oral presentations. I feel like the only way you could get a 7/7 is if Chinese is your first language! That should not be the case in a beginners class where we all work really hard.
reviews.comment_workload: No homework, only out-of-class assignment was the essay. But the amount I had to study for the course was definitely too much. In terms of studying, might be highest workload from my 5 courses.

-
Unit One vocabs

-
from part 1 to part 4 (number-related topics)

1) Introduce yourself, your family and one of your friends.
2) Tell the daily, weekly, monthly and yearly schedule of yourself.

Assessment 3

*Oral (3 min.) (Weighting 10%)

reviews.comment_content: The content covered basic vocabulary which is relevant for beginners. This includes the number, greeting, introducing, date and time, foods, etc.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor always inserts knowledge about Chinese culture between the lesson which is very useful for the essay.

Also, it was very easy to reach her and she can answer your doubts very well.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is fair and you can work for A


Assessment 1 (20%)
pronunciation 10%
listening 10%
Chanpter 1-3

Assessment 2 (20%)
oral 10%
listening 10%
Chapter 4-7

Assessment 3 (50%)
oral 10%
listening 10%
grammar 20%
character recognition* 10%
chapter 8-10

Essay of around 1000 English words
Chinese culture* 10%

The attendant is mandatory. However, you can be absence for 5 times. (The add-drop period attendant is counted)
reviews.comment_workload: There is homework but not marked by the professor. However, the homework really helps to understand the lesson better and it really helps to prepare for the assessments.

reviews.author: Anisha
reviews.title: Excellent course
reviews.comment_content: The content is well built-up throughout the semester and is divided reasonably between 3 assessments. You will be tested on speaking, listening, grammar and translation. There are no midterms or finals. Each lesson focuses on a specific important topic that we need to learn in mandarin in the basic level. Even though the amount of content gets kinda overwhelming at the end, if you have practiced mandarin a bit every other day and attended all the classes, you are good to go. There is also an essay due at the end on a any one aspect of the Chinese culture and personally, I had fun working on it.
reviews.comment_teaching: Zhou Tong (Mandy) is a brilliant teacher. She is very meticulous and will teach a lot in a short amount of time but trust me when I say she gets them ingrained in your mind. She also makes sure we know exactly what we will be tested on and makes us practice in class accordingly. She will also answer any questions you have in class and after. Mandy was really considerate when I informed her that I was sick the day before the final assessment and tried to help me out as much as she could.
reviews.comment_grading: The final assessment weighs 50% of the final grade and the rest consists of the other 2 assessments, essay and attendance. Grading is absolute where 95+ is A+, 90+ is A, 85+ is A- and so forth. If you miss 5 or more classes, you will fail the course. The essay is graded according to content and not language so it is easy to score high. It is a good course to take if you want to score high but it takes constant effort.
reviews.comment_workload: There are no assignments but Mandy will ask to learn vocabularies almost every class. She will make you start learning Chinese characters much earlier than the other instructors and I suggest you do so because it is impossible to learn about 80 of them in like a week. Other than that, just attend the classes and you're good.

reviews.author: Willnat
reviews.title: Very Good for Chinese Newbies
reviews.comment_content: This course discusses the basic and fundamental conversations, materials of Chinese Language. Overall, you are taught about how to order food and drinks, explain from your daily to yearly activities, greet people, make appointments, etc. It is useful for Chinese beginners.
reviews.comment_teaching: Laoshi Zhou Tong gives clear explanations. She speaks English clearly and understandably. She is a generous teacher. She understands that people taking this course aren't that a top notch of Mandarin. That is why she tolerate slight mistakes made by the students. And, there is a book for this course made by the teaching team in UST, LANG1120 Chinese. Basically, what she taught is from this book. It is useful and not that long of explanations and all.
reviews.comment_grading: Very generous grading... for this level you don't have to memorize all the tones of the Pinyins. There are speaking and also listening parts of the tests. People usually find it hard when it comes to speaking. It is a bit troublesome because you have to prepare the notes for it and you are not able to read the notes. But since this is a language class, you can do a little bit of improvisation in the middle in case something slips of your mind.
reviews.comment_workload: Few workload, since it is mostly not graded. But you might have to do it to improve your Chinese. Mainly, only homework from the book. Translating dialogues, memorizing necessary vocabularies. Sometimes you have to spend some time on Pinyin and maybe preparing for speaking. But it is, after all, a language course, so it is expected to have those kinds of homework and tasks.

reviews.author: Saksham
reviews.comment_content: The course content is really useful for students learning chinese for the first time. it covers topics from greetings, food, time, price, hobbies and some other daily conversations.
reviews.comment_teaching: Liang xin is an amazing teacher. She is very encouraging of questions and is also willing to help if just you are having difficulty with any specific portion. overall the class is a lot of fun,
reviews.comment_grading: the grading in the course is okay. there are three assessments and an essay that you have to write, with the final assessment bearing the majority of the grade.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is honestly not too much if you'e paying attention in class and keeping up with all the coursework.

reviews.author: Temirlan
reviews.comment_content: You will learn the basic Mandarin. This is the lowest Chinese language level designed for students with no background in this language. The course consists of 3-4 units, where you will learn phrases and words used in daily life. At the end of the course you will have to memorize up to 90 character words.
reviews.comment_teaching: Teacher is very good and passionate about her subject. Apart from the course materials she often taught us additional words used in China in nowadays. Every lesson started with short not assessed quiz about the topic covered in the last class.
reviews.comment_grading:
3 assignments:
Assignment 1 (20%) - Listening, covering units 1-3;
Assignment 2 (20%) - Listening & Oral self-introduction, covering units 4-7;
Assignment 3 (50%) - Oral self-introduction & Listening covering units 8-10, and Grammar and Characters covering materials of the entire course.

Additional:
Essay about Chinese culture, 1000 words. (10%)

Attendance is not included into the grade. However 5 absences will result in F grade for the course.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is light. Teacher rarely gives the homework, and most of the times it takes 20min. However, in order to prepare for the assignments its better to revise the material after every class. Starting from the second half of the semester its better to start memorizing characters.

reviews.author: ada18234e
reviews.comment_content: You learn the basics and more in the class. You follow the book format in terms of how much vocabulary is taught. There are roughly 8-9 lessons, on average you spend about 1 lesson every 2 class. You'll learn self-introductions, useful phrases when shopping, and other phrases that can help you get around.
reviews.comment_teaching: I have previous teachers try to teach me Mandarin, and she Mrs. Zhou is actually one of the very first that I enjoyed. She is not really strict and willing to answer beyond what your original question was, therefore, giving you more insight on the knowledge. She is also quite funny and enthusiastic to teach.
reviews.comment_grading: She definitely understood that students did not really have good tones, so grading was a little more lenient as lone as you tried. Attendance is part of the grade and there about 3 "tests" that factor into your grade. Each test varies but the first one is about 20%, second is 25% and the last one is around 30%.
reviews.comment_workload: 3 exams, 1 essay that is written in English, it only has to be about 1000 words. She does occasionally assign homework but none that she grades nor checks. Its just something she expect for next class like translating 1 of the dialouges and coming prepared to class with it

reviews.author: Mew
reviews.comment_content:
The content mainly covered some basic grammar and vocabulary, but as an introductory course, it isn't really sufficient for daily conversation based on my experiences with the hall cleaner...

It mainly talks about introducing yourself, dates, numbers, foods, and sports.
reviews.comment_teaching: Nuo Min was an excellent teacher and she's very nice. In about every class, she writes a useful summary of the vocab and grammar on the board. She gives plenty of opportunities to ask questions for clarification and you can even email her to ask to see her out of class (though she is often busy with other classes) especially to check your script for the oral assessments.
reviews.comment_grading:
The course included 3 assessments and 1 essay on any aspect of Chinese culture.

There is a listening section on each assessment worth 10 points each, and the difficulty gradually increased, but if you did the exercises on the CLE website, it should not be too difficult.

The first assessment had a pronunciation section where you were given a list of words in pinyin and had to pronounce them correctly. In the second and third assessments, this was replaced with an oral section where you would have to speak for quite a while without a script using words covered in the lesson. It is very hard to get full on the oral assessments but in general, using a lot of words will get you a higher score since it seems they have a list of words from the lesson and record which grammatical structures or vocabularies you use. Each pronunciation or oral section is worth 10 points.

The last assessment also included a Chinese character section and a grammar section, each worth 10 points. For the character section, you're given a list of 70 words and you should be able to recognize (though you don't have to write them) all of them. Doing the exercises on the website should be sufficient preparation. The grammar section tested grammar points covered in the book.

The essay had to be around 1000 words and could be on anything in Chinese culture and is worth 10 points.

In my opinion, it is quite hard to get A+, but it is definitely possible.
reviews.comment_workload:
As a LANG course, attendance is mandatory and you can only skip 6 or so lessons without failing.

For me, the listening assessments took around 1 hour to prepare for each, but for the oral assessments I needed to prepare a script and this did take a lot of effort.

reviews.author: fmartello
reviews.comment_content:
It is an introductory Chinese level and does not cover much about characters, there is only one final recognition test in the final.

The listening part gets harder in each exam, but nothing impossible.

It is easy to fall behind if you don't go to class.
reviews.comment_teaching: Nuo Min is really nice and she's super helpful before oral presentations and just in general if you have any doubt and clarification. She's also really good at transmitting interest about Chinese culture. If you put in effort she will be really helpful and it will be easy to get a good grade
reviews.comment_grading: This class doesn't follow a traditional curve; usually 85% is A-, 90% is and 95% is A+. It's hard to get A+ because it's almost impossible to get full score in the orals and in the cultural essay. However A is absolutely feasible. If you skip more than 5 classes you automatically fail. Rather than that, pretty hard to fail this class.
reviews.comment_workload: It's really hard to catch up if you fall behind, but there's nothing mandatory outside of class. There's one cultural essay (less than a 1000 words) in English in the end.

reviews.author: abdrassilovak
reviews.comment_content:
Basic Pinyin (pronunciation, memorization of 100 Chinese characters, 1000 words essay on comparison of Chinese culture to your own).
Topics include self-introduction, food, numbers, hobbies, time.
3 exams, no final.
reviews.comment_teaching: Good communication with the teacher, clear explanations of the criteria and what is going to be there on the exam.
reviews.comment_grading:
Absolute grading.
Attendance is important, as if you skip five classes, then you get a F.
reviews.comment_workload:
If you read through the book and practice regularly, then not that much workload.
Plenty of time to write an essay and you can discuss on the topic with the teacher.

reviews.author: conandy
reviews.comment_content: Basic Chinese. Mostly pronunciation and pin yin. Chinese characters barely used
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Min is a great lecturer and gives wonderful introduction to Chinese language.
reviews.comment_grading: While it's all about competition in this university, this is the only type of course which allows you to spare your breath. You are graded on an absolute grading system. 95 = A+, 90 = A, 85 = B+, and so on.
reviews.comment_workload: Not so much to do as long as you attend all the courses (btw, if you miss more than 5 classes it's an automatic F) and try to practice the pin yin every now and then.

reviews.author: ddd
reviews.title: great class
reviews.comment_content: always the same, you can refer to other reviews, it's pretty basic
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Liang Xin is a great teacher, one of the best I met at UST. If you get a chance to choose her group, don't hesitate. Her attitude is very positive and if you come to the classes and participate at least a bit, she will appreciate it. The learning process feels very smooth and easy from the perspective of a person with no Chinese language background.
reviews.comment_grading: very good, for all the assignment got ~90% which was A+
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is quite big due to the attendance requirements (if you come usually you need to know what was going on in the last class) and 3 assignments distributed throughout the semester. However, if you work systematically and don't procrastinate, you will find it entertaining and won't feel it's too much.

reviews.author: KITN
reviews.comment_content:
http://cle.ust.hk/courses/lang1120/content/#content
The link above has details on course content. The course covers basic topics such as introduction,hobbies,date and time,food,etc. It is mostly helpful
reviews.comment_teaching: Rao is hardworking and and explains everything clearly. However she sometimes has problem understanding our doubts. She makes the course fun and interesting
reviews.comment_grading: I think the course difficulty a tad too high. That being said if you study regularily you can score well. There are two mid-terms and a final exam. A 1000-word essay has to be written in english about Chinese culture.
reviews.comment_workload: You need to put in effort and time into this course. The last few chapters are tough and you will be required to learn a lot of new words in a limited period of time. We were told about characters right before the final exam and thus it was really difficult to properly prepare for them so make sure to study the characters after each chapter.

reviews.author: Pajuju
reviews.comment_content: I think the content of the course was adequately designed. For a student without any background in Chinese, the course was not too difficult to follow yet had crucial parts in speaking Mandarin.
reviews.comment_teaching: Nuo Min was a great teacher. She understands that most of us really don't have any background in Chinese and she really tries to teach us both the language and the cultures of China. Although sometimes, when doing grammar, the class can get boring, most of the times it is a very warm atmosphere.
reviews.comment_grading: It is really difficult to get 7s on the oral and the only way to really get higher mark in the orals is just by talking for a very long time, using every single vocab you know. As others have mentioned, I think 90+ gets an A and so forth. If you put in the work, getting an A is not a difficult task.
reviews.comment_workload: It is not too heavy yet also not so light. With no background, if you do not put in the effort, I don't think you can do very well in this course. However, as mentioned previously, you will get a very honest output in this course so put the work in!

reviews.author: Schr
reviews.comment_content: relaxed and entertaining atmosphere, but demanding course content.
reviews.comment_teaching: sometimes a bit quick but all in all very good to keep up with. especially the first few lectures with the pronunciation can be a bit confusing, as the different characters as well as the pronunciation need to be remembered
reviews.comment_grading: don´t now yet, as results are not there yet. however as to be red in the older review, grading should be adequate to the learning input.
reviews.comment_workload: considerably low if weekly studying throughout the semester is conducted. in exam however, luck plays still a role.

reviews.author: YSA
reviews.comment_content:
http://cle.ust.hk/courses/lang1120/content/#content
See the course website for details about course content. Mostly general topics like introductions and greetings, numbers, time and date, hobbies, food and drink.
While some of the content is useful to be able to communicate in Chinese, a lot of it is not, like the arbitrary selection of 100-150 Chinese characters.
reviews.comment_teaching: Emma Rao is a great teacher. She is patient and explains concepts, grammar rules, etc. clearly and always helps with any questions or problems. She keeps providing useful hints and advise and tries to make the content fun and relevant.
reviews.comment_grading:
http://cle.ust.hk/courses/lang1120/content/#assessment
See the course website for assessment details.
The course difficulty level is too high in my opinion. This is supposed to be the 1st in an 8-course series, but I think the introductory course should be much easier. Most language courses cover this amount of material in 1-2 years.
This course uses absolute grading, not curved, which could be better or worse for you. The grade boundaries are not revealed, but are around 70+% for C, 80+% for B, 90+% for A.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is moderate for an introductory Common Core course. The main 'assignment' is a 1000-word English essay about Chinese culture, which is quite easy but takes some time to research and write. Apart from that a lot of time is spent on regular revision and preparation of oral presentations for the various written, listening, and oral assessments which happen around every 3 weeks.

reviews.author: Diego
reviews.title: Chinese 1 Review
reviews.comment_content: The content of the class is pretty useful, you learn the basics of Chinese conversation along with likes, dislikes, food, drinks, etc. You learn some characters and the tones of the words. The one thing I wish I would have learned was more verbs. In the end, I came out of that class much more knowledgeable than I had expected. The character study helps a lot if you're planning on traveling to China as well.
reviews.comment_teaching: Nuo Min was a great teacher. She pushes you to learn more Chinese while still taking the course at the right pace. We listened a lot to fast conversations, which was hard to understand, but made us way better at understanding Chinese. Very happy with her teaching.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading was very fair. You get what you put into it, and it was not hard to get an A if you studied weekly. For anyone taking this class, study listening a lot before tests, this seemed to be the toughest part of each test consistently. There are two "mid-terms" and one "final" exam along with an essay. Make sure to study the characters weekly - it will help you a lot for the final exam character section!
reviews.comment_workload: Once again, the workload was more about how much you put into it. I felt that this class was easier than some of my other classes (Business courses), but I still put a decent amount of work into this class each week to get a good grade. I think that if anything, we could have done more assignments and work to learn more.

reviews.author: avv
reviews.comment_content:
Introductory level course to Mandarin Chinese for people with non-Chinese background. In my opinion, the course can be a bit hard if you do not revise somewhat regularly and if you have absolutely not studied any Chinese before. Vocabulary and sentences is mainly taught through Pinyin- a writing system where Chinese characters are written using Latin Alphabet. And recognition of about 100 Chinese characters will be tested in the last assessment.

Absence for more than 5 classes in the semester will result in a F grade.
reviews.comment_teaching: The instructor is fairly good and always helpful in class. The pace is slow till the first assessment. After that it suddenly picks up and we rushed through in the last two weeks to finish the syllabus in time before the last assessment.
reviews.comment_grading: Like other LANG courses, LANG1120 is not graded on a curve. Absolute grading is followed.
reviews.comment_workload:
1. Assessment 1 (20% of final grade) :  Chapters 1-3
  a) Listening Comprehension
  b) Speaking- pronunciation
  
2. Assessment 2 (20% of final grade): Chapters 4-7
a) Listening Comprehension
b) Speaking- Oral speech around 3 min

3. Assessment 3 (50% of final grade): Chapters 8-10
   a) Listening comprehension
   b) Speaking- Oral speech
   c) Grammar test- will cover the entire book
   d) Character recognition- List of characters are given in the book as well as a list will be provided by the teacher. Highly recommended to do the character exercises consistently throughout the semester.

4. Essay on Chinese Culture (10% of final grade) - written in English (APA style) and focus must be on any one aspect of the Chinese Culture.
And additionally the teacher may expect students to do the textbook exercises as homework to be discussed later in class.

reviews.author: Dok
reviews.comment_content:
Introduction to Mandarin. A little challenging if you're learning Chinese for the first time ever. Mostly use pinyin throughout the course, only need to be able to recognize (not write) certain characters.

3 assessments (each worth 20%, 20%, 50%)
and an essay on a topic relevant to Chinese culture (10%)

Need to attend class; 6 or more absences will result in an F.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Instructors are helpful and nice.
Textbook is used. Not very expensive. < 50 HK$
Pace is slow at first, but speeds up a lot by the end
reviews.comment_grading:
Absolute grading (not on a curve)
I believe 95%+ will get you an A+, and 90%+ an A.
reviews.comment_workload:
Assessment 1 - Chapters 1-3
Listening & Speaking. Very easy
Assessment 2 - Chapters 4-7
Listening & Speaking
Assessment 3 - Chapters 8-10
Listening, Speaking, Grammar, Character recognition
Cultural essay
Essay on a topic relevant to Chinese culture

There will be assignments (in textbooks) but it's optional.

reviews.author: itand
reviews.title: Very time consuming
reviews.comment_content: The content is for beginners and covers several different topics that will be useful for conversation.  Has 10 lessons in total. But we also have to memorise 100 characters by the end of the semester.
reviews.comment_teaching: Nuo, Min was a very good teacher. She was always willing to answer questions and encouraged us to repeat after her for pronunciation and answer questions which helped to learn. She would also encourage us to book one-on-one sessions with her after class and be very helpful and explain really well. However, when it came to vocab, it was a bit rushed as vocab memorisation is completely on you. Also, during lessons, when she is teaching vocab it can get a bit boring but overall she engages the class well.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is very very strict. It is not curved, it has absolute marking. But it is near impossible to get full marks, and very hard to get good grades. Especially for oral, getting 6/7 was the absolute best you can expect to do. Same with the essay. It does have a lot of different exams/test and you have to do you're absolute best for each test.
reviews.comment_workload: I think that the course has a lot of workload. It constantly has exams and you cannot slack off for even a week. Every week maybe one or even two lessons are taught with a lot of new vocabulary. You have to prepare for character recognition test and grammar test from the beginning of the semester otherwise you will have a lot of content to memorize for the final exam. Keep reviewing characters, grammar, and vocab regularly. Also, practice pronunciation with a Chinese speaking friend to get better marks

reviews.author: jjjj0252
